justification: Some attempt to appeal to B’s desire for stability (“stable workhorse RB”), but it ignores B’s conservative preference for proven veterans and high-powered offenses—Robinson is a rookie in a low-volume attack. It also asks B to give up a Tier 2 TE (Noah Brown) despite B valuing reliability, with only a Tier 4 fallback. Calling it a consolidation trade is inaccurate (2-for-2). Reasoning is generic and not grounded in B’s roster or psychology.
